artists.name: Riccardo Muti
artists.bio: Riccardo Muti, born in Naples, Italy, is one of the most celebrated and respected conductors of our time. With a career spanning over five decades, Muti has led many of the world's most prestigious orchestras, including the Berlin Philharmonic, the Vienna Philharmonic, and the New York Philharmonic. He has been the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra since 2010, where he has been praised for his dynamic leadership and innovative programming. Muti is renowned for his interpretations of the works of Verdi, Beethoven, and Mozart, and his commitment to preserving the classical music tradition while also championing contemporary composers. His numerous accolades include the Grammy Award, the Birgit Nilsson Prize, and the Prince of Asturias Award for the Arts. Muti is also known for his dedication to music education and outreach, having founded the Luigi Cherubini Youth Orchestra and frequently conducting free concerts for the public.

artists.name: Yuja Wang
artists.bio: Yuja Wang, born in Beijing, China, is a world-renowned classical pianist known for her extraordinary technical skill and captivating stage presence. A child prodigy, Wang began her piano studies at the age of six and quickly rose to international prominence. She studied at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing, the Mount Royal Conservatory in Calgary, and the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. Wang's performances are characterized by their energy, precision, and emotional depth, and she is equally at home with the works of Chopin, Rachmaninoff, and Prokofiev. Her bold fashion choices and charismatic personality have made her a favorite among audiences worldwide. Wang has performed with leading orchestras such as the Berlin Philharmonic, the London Symphony Orchestra, and the New York Philharmonic, and she has collaborated with esteemed conductors including Gustavo Dudamel, Michael Tilson Thomas, and Valery Gergiev. Her discography includes critically acclaimed recordings for Deutsche Grammophon, and she has received numerous awards, including the Echo Klassik Award and the Gramophone Award.

artists.name: Chicago Symphony Orchestra
artists.bio: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra (CSO) is one of the most prestigious and storied orchestras in the world. Founded in 1891, the CSO has a rich history of excellence and innovation in classical music. The orchestra has been led by a succession of legendary music directors, including Frederick Stock, Fritz Reiner, Sir Georg Solti, and Daniel Barenboim. Under their leadership, the CSO has developed a distinctive sound characterized by its power, precision, and warmth. The orchestra is renowned for its interpretations of the works of Mahler, Bruckner, and Shostakovich, and it has premiered numerous contemporary compositions. The CSO performs at Symphony Center in Chicago and tours extensively, bringing its music to audiences around the globe. The orchestra's recordings have earned 63 Grammy Awards, more than any other orchestra in the world. In addition to its performances, the CSO is committed to music education and community engagement, offering a wide range of programs for young musicians and music lovers of all ages.

artists.name: Jessie Montgomery
artists.bio: Jessie Montgomery is an acclaimed American composer and violinist whose work is celebrated for its innovation, vibrancy, and emotional depth. Born and raised in New York City, Montgomery began her musical journey at a young age, studying violin at the prestigious Juilliard School. Her compositions draw on a wide range of influences, from classical and jazz to folk and spirituals, reflecting her diverse cultural heritage and experiences. Montgomery's music is known for its rhythmic vitality, lyrical melodies, and rich harmonies, and it often explores themes of social justice, identity, and community. Her works have been performed by leading ensembles such as the New York Philharmonic, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and the Sphinx Virtuosi, and she has received numerous commissions from prestigious organizations. Montgomery is also a dedicated educator and advocate for diversity in classical music, serving as a faculty member at the Mannes School of Music and as a composer-in-residence with the Sphinx Organization.

program.notes: Hymn for Everyone is a reflective and inclusive piece that showcases Jessie Montgomery's unique voice and style. Composed in 2020, the work is a response to the social and political upheavals of the time, offering a message of hope and unity. The piece is characterized by its lyrical melodies, rich harmonies, and rhythmic vitality, drawing on a wide range of influences from classical and jazz to folk and spirituals. Montgomery's use of texture and color creates a soundscape that is both intimate and expansive, inviting listeners to reflect on their own experiences and connections to the world around them. Hymn for Everyone has been praised for its emotional depth and accessibility, making it a favorite among performers and audiences alike.

program.pieceName: Piano Concerto No. 3 in C Major
program.notes: Sergei Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3 in C major, Op. 26, is one of the most popular and frequently performed works in the piano concerto repertoire. Composed between 1917 and 1921, the concerto is a dazzling showcase of Prokofiev's virtuosic piano writing and innovative orchestration. The first movement, Andante - Allegro, opens with a lyrical theme introduced by the clarinet, which is then developed and transformed through a series of contrasting sections. The second movement, Theme and Variations, features a simple, folk-like theme that undergoes a series of imaginative and colorful variations, highlighting Prokofiev's gift for melody and invention. The final movement, Allegro ma non troppo, is a tour de force of rhythmic energy and technical brilliance, culminating in a thrilling and triumphant conclusion. Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3 is celebrated for its combination of lyricism, wit, and virtuosity, and it remains a favorite among pianists and audiences worldwide.

Johannes Brahms' Symphony No. 4 in E minor, Op. 98, is widely regarded as one of the greatest symphonic works of the 19th century. Composed in 1884-1885, it is Brahms' final symphony and a culmination of his symphonic writing. The first movement, Allegro non troppo, is characterized by its sweeping melodies and intricate development, showcasing Brahms' mastery of form and counterpoint. The second movement, Andante moderato, offers a lyrical and introspective contrast, with its warm harmonies and expressive themes. The third movement, Allegro giocoso, is a lively and spirited scherzo, full of rhythmic vitality and playful energy. The symphony concludes with the fourth movement, Allegro energico e passionato, a powerful and dramatic passacaglia based on a theme from Bach's Cantata No. 150. Brahms' Symphony No. 4 is celebrated for its emotional depth, structural complexity, and rich orchestration, and it remains a cornerstone of the symphonic repertoire.
